title: R44325
content: The level of pay for congressional staff is determined by Senate committees, with job titles, pay rates, and resources set by the chair and ranking Member. Congressional pay data is sought for various reasons, such as assessing costs, setting pay levels, and comparing with other federal government systems. However, aggregated pay data for congressional staff is not readily available from public sources. The data in this report is based on official Senate reports, providing consistently collected data on pay. The pay levels for staff in Senate committees are determined by the chair and ranking Member. Data in this report is based on official Senate reports, collected and organized by LegiStorm. It provides pay data for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees. This report by LegiStorm provides annual data on Senate committee staff compensation by fiscal year. It includes pay data for 13 staff position titles used in Senate committees since FY2001. Position titles were identified through a two-step process, excluding titles filled by only one staff member and those used by six or fewer panels. In FY2014, 277 titles were filled by only one staff member and excluded. 25 titles were assessed for staff employment in Senate committees. 12 position titles used by six or fewer panels were excluded. Pay data was collected for the remaining 13 positions, requiring data from at least five committees. Data for no more than two staff per committee with the same job title were collected. Staff had to hold the same job title in the same committee for the entire fiscal year and not receive pay from any other congressional authority to be included. In FY2014, pay data for Senate committee staff with the same job title in the same committee for the entire fiscal year was collected. The data includes all payments made to these staff members, which may differ from their stated annual salary due to additional payments like overtime or bonuses. Pay data for House committee staff is available in another report, while data for personal office staff of Senators and Members of the House is available in a separate CRS report. Pay data for congressional staff working in House committee offices and personal offices of Senators and Members of the House are available in CRS reports. The data may not represent all positions held by Senate committee staff due to the large number of titles held by one employee. Staff titles assignment could impact findings and interpretation of the data. The data on pay for Senate committee staff may not be fully representative due to the large number of titles held by one employee. Two categories of positions were identified, with pay information likely to be accurate for positions usually held by one staff member per committee. Positions where multiple staff members could be hired have limited pay data available. The pay data for Senate committee staff may not fully represent all positions due to the variety of titles held by one employee. Pay information is likely accurate for positions typically held by one staff member per committee, while positions with potential for multiple hires have limited pay data available. The data does not consider factors such as education, work experience, or job duties, and assumes staff with the same title perform similar tasks. The data provided does not consider factors like education, work experience, or job duties, which may affect levels of compensation. Differences in job duties for staff with the same title are acknowledged, leading to potential variations in pay. Congressional job titles are imprecise, with individuals carrying out vastly different tasks. Tables in this section offer background information on Senate pay practices and detailed data for each position. Tables in this section provide background information on Senate pay practices, comparative data for each position, and detailed data and visualizations for Senate committee staff pay rates since 2001. Constant dollar calculations are based on the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers (CPI-U) for various years. Cumulative percentage changes in median pay for each position, Members of Congress, and salaries under the General Schedule are also provided. The text provides data on Senate committee staff pay rates since 2001, including cumulative percentage changes in median pay for different positions. Tables and graphics show pay data in nominal and constant 2016 dollars, comparing positions to Members of Congress and federal civilian workers. Between FY2011 and FY2015, median pay changes ranged from a 16.93% increase for professional staff members to a -16.48% decrease for staff assistants. Two positions saw pay increases while seven saw declines out of seven staff positions with available data. Comparatively, Members of Congress had a -5.10% pay change and General Schedule, DC had a -3.19% change over the same period. Between FY2006 and FY2015, median pay changes ranged from a 22.01% increase for senior counsels to a -26.72% decrease for staff assistants. Out of eight staff positions with available data, four saw pay increases and four saw declines. Comparatively, Members of Congress had a -10.41% pay change and General Schedule, DC had a -0.13% change over the same period. Between FY2001 and FY2015, median pay changes for staff positions ranged from a 30.88% increase for systems administrators to a -26.67% decrease for staff assistants. Out of seven staff positions with available data, five saw pay increases while two saw declines. Comparatively, Members of Congress had a -10.40% pay change and General Schedule, DC had a 7.36% change over the same period.
